title: My Child Is Too Slow at Addition and Subtraction – How to Speed Up
description: Practical strategies to improve basic arithmetic fluency without causing stress or rushing.

content.intro: Your child can do 8+7. It just takes them 10 seconds. By the time they calculate one problem, other kids are done with three. Here's how to build faster fluency.

sections.text: Why Basic Facts Need to Be Fast
When basic facts are slow, everything downstream suffers:
Fluency with basic facts is the foundation. It's like reading – you need to recognize words automatically to focus on comprehension.

rows: Process all facts the same way

sections.text: Before drilling speed, make sure they understand what addition and subtraction mean. Use objects, drawings, number lines.
3. Focus on Fewer Facts at a Time
Don't practice all 100+ facts at once. Master 2-3 new facts at a time. Then add more.
5 minutes daily beats 30 minutes weekly. Consistency builds automaticity.
Card games, dice games, math video games – anything that gets repetition without feeling like work.
The goal is automaticity – answering without conscious thought. Like how you don't think about spelling your name, you just write it. Math facts should feel the same.

items: Solid fluency with most facts: 2-3 months

sections.text: Be patient. Building neural pathways takes time, but it's permanent once established.

faq.question: Are timed tests helpful or harmful?
faq.answer: It depends on the child. For some, timed practice is motivating. For anxious kids, it's counterproductive. Read your child – if timed tests cause tears, stop using them.

faq.question: My child still uses fingers. Should I stop them?
faq.answer: Not forcibly. Fingers are a legitimate tool. But encourage strategies (doubles, make 10) that reduce finger dependence. The goal is to eventually not need fingers, but don't make fingers "wrong."

faq.question: What if they've already "learned" facts but are slow?
faq.answer: They've learned but not internalized. They need more practice with those specific facts. Use flashcards, games, or apps that target weak facts specifically.

cta.text: SoroKid builds basic fact fluency through adaptive practice – targeting exactly the facts your child needs to work on.
